title: A Refined Protocol for Identifying Citrulline-specific Monoclonal Antibodies from Single Human B Cells from Rheumatoid Arthritis Patient Material
procedures: Work for the recombinant antibody pipeline (Figure 1).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829004549_4565.jpgFigure 1. Human monoclonal antibody production pipeline. ELN: Electronic laboratory notebook. B cell receptor single-cell cloningCollection of single-cell sorted cells (approx. 5 h)Process cells and tissues and sort B cells according to your validated flow cytometry methodology.Sort single B cells into 96-well PCR plates containing 10 μl of sorting buffer (Table 1).Immediately cover each plate with adhesive PCR plate foil, spin down the plate and place it on dry ice until the cell sorting is finished. If not immediately used for the steps described below, store the plates in -80 °C freezer until further use.Table 1. Reagent preparation for cells sortingimgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829013037_3343.jpgSingle-cell reverse transcription (approx. 3 h)Thaw plate(s) of single-sorted B cells on ice and spin down before removing the adhesive PCR plate foil.Carefully add 6 μl of Random hexamer primers (RHP) mix (Table 2) to each well. Cover the plate with adhesive PCR plate seal and spin down.Transfer the plate on a hot plate for 1 min at 68 °C and put back on ice or onto the PCR-cooler.Carefully remove the adhesive PCR plate seal and add 14 μl RT mix (Table 2) to each well.Cover the plate with a new adhesive PCR plate seal and perform the reverse transcription at 42 °C for 5 min, 25 °C for 10 min, 50 °C for 60 min, and 95 °C for 5 min.The cDNA can be immediately used or stored at -80 °C before performing the PCRs.Table 2. Reagent preparation for reverse transcriptionimgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829013206_6258.jpgNotes: Before starting all steps in this section, it is important to clean the PCR hood or the laboratory bench and laboratory pipettes with ethanol, RNase away, and DNase away decontamination solutions.

Single-cell lysis and cDNA synthesis are performed in the original plate that was used for cell sorting, which minimizes the risk for cross-contamination.When you calculate the volume of each reagent that you need, add 10% of reagent volume overage (e.g., for a full 96-well PCR plate, calculate for 105 wells), so that all the wells are filled properly. High attention when working with single cells must be considered; even talking over the plate can cause contamination. It is also very important to cautiously remove the adhesive PCR plate seals to avoid splashes. Store cDNA at -80 °C until further use. Immunoglobulin variable region gene amplification (approx. 2 days)Prepare heavy chain, lambda and kappa chain PCR master mixes for the first PCR in 3 separate tubes as described in Table 3. The targeted gene segments are all indicated in the name of the primer in Appendix[href=https://os.bio-protocol.org/attached/file/20190827/Supplementary file Appendix.docx].Carefully add 38 μl of each PCR master mix 1 to the corresponding well and plate (heavy, kappa, or lambda) and then carefully add 3 μl of cDNA to each well. Cover with adhesive PCR plate seal and spin down.Perform the first PCR at 95 °C for 15 min; for 50 cycles at 95 °C for 30 s, 58 °C (IgH/Igκ) or 60 °C (Igλ) for 30 s, 72 °C for 55 s; 72 °C for 10 min.Prepare PCR master mixes for the second PCR, as shown in Table 3.Carefully add 37 μl of PCR master mix 2 to each well of the plate and then carefully add 3.5 μl of first PCR product to each well. Cover with adhesive PCR plate seal.

Perform the second PCR at 95 °C for 15 min; for 50 cycles at 95 °C for 30 s, 58 °C (IgH/Igκ) or 60 °C (Igλ) for 30 s, 72 °C for 45 s; 72 °C for 10 min.Check the size of the second PCR products by running a 2% agarose gel, and visualize the DNA bands using a UV transilluminator. Expected sizes of the second PCR are 510 bp for Igκ, 405 bp for Igλ, and 450 bp for IgH (Figure 2).Purify second PCR products using a PCR cleanup kit following the manufacturer’s instruction.Sequence the purified second PCR products using the respective primers describes in Appendix[href=https://os.bio-protocol.org/attached/file/20190827/Supplementary file Appendix.docx].imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829004633_3116.jpgFigure 2. Representative agarose gel picture of RT-PCR products of IgH (450 bp), Igλ (405 bp), and Igκ (510 bp) variable region genes amplified from single human B cells. Lane L: 100 bp DNA ladder.Table 3. PCR mix for 1st and 2nd PCRimgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829013342_3383.jpgNotes: When you calculate the volume of each reagent that you need, add 10% of reagent volume overage (e.g., for a full 96-well PCR plate, calculate for 105 wells), so that all the wells are filled properly. To ensure that the master mix is not contaminated, prepare each master mix with enough volume to have one buffer control. Heavy chain, lambda and kappa chain PCRs are always performed in separate plates.  PCR products can be immediately used or stored at -20 °C until further use.Ig gene-specific PCR (approx. 4 h)Use the data generated from the IMGT/V-QUEST to identify for each PCR product (IgH, Igκ, or Igλ) the closest germline IgV and IgJ gene and to define each gene-specific primer for each well using primers described in the Appendix[href=https://os.bio-protocol.org/attached/file/20190827/Supplementary file Appendix.docx] (Figure 3A).

Prepare a pipetting scheme indicating the correct primer pairs for each well and plate (heavy, kappa, or lambda) (Figure 3B).Dilute gene-specific primers to a working concentration of 5 nmol/ml in nuclease-free water.In a 96-well plate carefully add 2 μl of the matched 5′ and 3′ primers for each individual PCR product into the same well.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829004716_8862.jpgFigure 3. Example showing how to use the data generated from the IMGT/V-QUEST to identify the closest germline IgV and IgJ gene (A) and to define gene-specific primers for each sample (B)Cover the plate with adhesive PCR plate seal and spin down for 10 s.In the same plate with the primers, add 34 μl of the first PCR mix (as described in Table 3) in each well.Add 4 μl of unpurified first PCR product into the correct well corresponding to the matched primers.Seal the plate with adhesive PCR plate and spin down for 10 s.Perform the second round of PCR described in Step A3f.Check the size of the gene-specific PCR products as described in Step A3g (Figure 4).Purify gene-specific PCR products using a PCR cleanup kit following the manufacturer’s instruction.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829004745_7444.jpgFigure 4. Representative agarose gel picture of gene-specific products of IgH variable region genes. Lane L: 100 bp DNA ladder.Notes:It’s important to clean pipettes and the PCR hood with ethanol, RNAse away, and DNAse away decontamination solution. It’s important to work on ice or a PCR cooler. PCR products can be used immediately or stored at -20 °C until further use.PCR products digestion with restriction enzymes (approx. 3 h)Thaw purified PCR products from Step A4 and spin down.Prepare digestion mix 1 for IgH, Igκ, and Igλ as described in Table 4.Table 4. Restriction digestion mix 1imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829013818_3452.jpg§Enzymes used are Sall and AgeI for Heavy chain; AgeI for Kappa chain; Xhol and AgeI for Lambda chain.

Vortex mixes gently and spin down and carefully add 10 μl of the digestion mix 1 to each tube.Add 30 μl of purified PCR products to each tube, vortex and spin down.Incubate for 15 min at 37 °C in the heating block.Prepare digestion mix 2 for Igκ as described in Table 5.Table 5. Digestion mix 2imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829013845_0934.jpgSpin down the tube.Carefully add 10 μl of each mix to each tube, vortex gently and spin down.Incubate for 1 h at 55 °C in the heating block.Perform PCR clean-up for the digested product as described above.Notes:PCR products can be immediately used or stored at -20 °C until further use. It’s absolutely needed to get rid of any of ethanol before the elution because ligase enzyme can be inhibited by minute traces of ethanol. Ligation of PCR products to cloning expression vectors (approx. 5 h)Linearize the vectors using enzymes (AgeI and Sall for IgH vector; AgeI and BsiWI for Igκ vector; Xhol and AgeI for Igλ vector) and purify the cleaved plasmids using Qiagen gel purification following the manufacturer’s protocol.Prepare the ligation mix as described in Table 6 and add 28 μl to each tube.Table 6. Ligation miximgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829013933_6031.jpgCarefully add 20 μl of digested DNA to each tube.Add 2 μl of Quick ligase to each tube.Incubate for 15 min at 25 °C in the heating block.Put the tubes back on ice.Notes: For better ligation efficiency, the quantity of the expression vectors used should be around 60 ng/μl. A three-fold molar excess of insert DNA to vector should be used. The expression vectors are high copy number plasmids. High purity of cleaved vectors and PCR products is required for optimal results. To avoid self-ligation of the vector, ligase should always be added last. Transformation of DH5α cells (approx.

18 h with o/n incubation)Thaw chemically competent bacteria on ice. Mix gently and carefully transfer 40 μl of cells into the tube on ice.Carefully add 5 μl of ligation product to the tube/well.Mix gently and incubate for 30 min on ice.Heat chock bacteria cells at 42 °C for 30 s and place the tubes back on ice for 2 min.Add 150 μl LB medium (without ampicillin) to the tube.Incubate the tubes for 30 min at 37 °C with shaking at 225 rpm.Take LB-Ampicillin agar plates out of the cold room to warm and label them with the corresponding clone name.Spread around 150 μl of the bacteria cells onto the agar plate.Incubate plates overnight at 37 °C upside down.Cover agar plates with parafilm and save them at 4 °C.Note: Store agar plates at 4 °C until plasmids are sequenced and verified.Insert-check PCR (approx. 3 h)Prepare a PCR master mix for the insert-check PCR, as shown in Table 3. Using the primers: Ab sense/IgG int for heavy; Ab sense/xholI for lambda; and Ab sense/Cκ494 for Kappa.Pick two to four colonies with 10 μl pipette tips from each plate, spread the colony on a backup LB agar plate, and then place the same pipette tips, each in a different well of a 96-well PCR plate containing the insert-check PCR mix.Perform the second PCR at 95 °C for 15 min; for 25 cycles at 95 °C for 30 s, 58 °C for 30 s, 72 °C for 60 s; 72 °C for 10 min.Check the size of the PCR products by running a 2% agarose gel, and visualize the DNA bands using a UV transilluminator. Expected sizes: 700 bp for Igκ, 590 bp for Igλ, and 650 bp for IgH (Figure 5).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829004921_1458.jpgFigure 5.

Representative agarose gel picture of insert check PCR products of IgH variable region genes. Lane L: 100 bp DNA ladder. P: positive control. Blue arrow: expected size of positive colonies. Red arrow: expected size of negative colonies.Plasmid miniprep (approx. 2 days with o/n incubation)For each sample, pick 4 insert positives colonies from the backup plate using a 200 μl pipette tip and inoculate 4 ml LB medium containing 100 μg/ml ampicillin in 15 ml culture tubes.Incubate the tubes overnight at 37 °C with shaking at 225 rpm.After incubation, pellet bacteria by centrifuging the culture tubes for 10 min at 3360 x g. Discard the supernatant.Purify plasmids using a miniprep kit following the manufacturer’s instruction.Sequence the plasmid DNA using the (Ab sense primer) to confirm the identity with the second PCR product.Notes: Before starting the plasmid miniprep make glycerol stocks of each culture by mixing 300 μl of 1:1 sterile LB/glycerol and 400 μl of the inoculate to a 2 ml tubes, mix well and freeze at -80 °C. It’s necessary to check the complete sequence in order to verify that the PCR product is ligated in-frame within the plasmid without any introduced errors. It’s also important to check the signal peptide and the constant region sequences are correct. Sometimes miniprep sequences may not be high enough quality to generate complete sequences and it is important to repeat the procedure. Exploratory screening of monoclonal antibodies (mAbs)Small scale production of mAbs (approx. 8 days with incubation)Mix 1.27 μg of total plasmid DNA for each 1 ml of cell suspension transfected. Half with heavy chain (0.635 μg/ml cell suspension) and half with light chain (0.635 μg/ml cell suspension). We recommend 30 ml cultures with 19 μg light chain and 19 μg heavy chain DNA for the initial screening.

Weigh in PEI-MAX and dissolve it in OptiPRO serum free media (sfm) to make the working solution (100 μg/ml) and sterile filter the solution through a 0.22 μm filter, you need 0.05 ml working solution per ml of cell suspension to transfect.Adjust the concentration of the Expi293 cells to 2.5 x 106 cells/ml and aliquot cell suspensions to labeled cell culture shaker flasks and put the flasks into the incubator (8% CO2, 37 °C, and 125 rpm on an orbital shaker).Add working solution of PEI-MAX in OptiPRO sfm to the tubes with DNA plasmids (0.05 ml/ml cell suspension). Mix by brief vortexing and incubate for exactly 10 min at room temperature.Add the mix DNA plasmids/PEI-MAX in OptiPRO sfm media drop-wise to the cell suspension.Put the flasks back into the incubator as soon as possible.Incubate at 37 °C, 125 rpm for 6 days.After incubation, pour the cell suspension into 50 ml tubes.Centrifuge the cells for 30 min at 840 x g at room temperature.Decant the supernatant by slowly pouring into new 50 ml tubes. The cell pellet should not be disrupted.Centrifuge the supernatant for 20 min at 10,000 x g, room temperature.Filter IgG through a 0.22 μm syringe filter.Notes: The day before transfection, dilute the Expi293 cells in the EXPI293 expression medium to 1.8 x 106 cells/ml. The most critical for the expression is that the Expi293 cells are in a good growth phase and with high viability. Always sterile filter all reagents and plasmids preparations before transfection.  Always use freshly prepared PEI-MAX working solutions. During the 6 days incubation, there is no need to passage the cells or change the medium. Filter the supernatant under sterile conditions. lgG in the supernatant are stable at 4 °C for a couple of weeks, but purification is recommended as soon as possible.

Purification of mAbs (approx. 2 days)Vortex Protein G Sepharose 4 Fast Flow beads and shake bottle vigorously. Add enough beads for 100 μl per sample to a 50 ml tube containing DPBS.Wash beads by centrifuging for 10 min at 840 x g, room temperature. Take off supernatant using a pipette, then centrifuge again using the same program. Resuspend Protein G in DPBS to achieve a total volume of 400 μl per sample.Add 400 μl of Protein G into each tube containing the supernatant.Incubate the tubes containing supernatants and Protein G for at least 14 h at 4 °C under 25 rpm rotation.After incubation, centrifuge supernatants for 20 min at 840 x g, room temperature. In the meantime, prepare a 2 ml microtube containing 100 μl 1 M Tris (pH 8.0).Discard supernatant without disrupting pellet. Leave about 1 ml of the supernatant at the bottom with the beads.Resuspend the beads in the remaining supernatant, and transfer to the empty Bio-spin chromatography column.Wash the Protein G column three times with 2 ml DPBS each.Blot the bottom of the Bio-spin chromatography column on a paper tissue to get rid of excess flow through droplets.Add 1 ml of filtered 0.1 M glycine (pH 3.0) to the protein G resin in the Bio-spin chromatography column to elute the IgG into a 2 ml Eppendorf tube. Immediately mix with the neutralization buffer (1 M Tris, pH 8.0).Change buffer to PBS using Zeba Spin 5 ml centrifugation desalting columns.Remove the Zeba spin column’s bottom closure and place the column into a 15 ml collection tube and centrifuge at 1,000 x g, discard flow-through and replace the column into the collection tube.Add 2.5 ml sterile DPBS to the column. Centrifuge at 1,000 x g and discard flow-through. Repeat this step two additional times.

Blot the bottom of the column to remove excess liquid. Transfer the device to a new collection tube. Apply the eluted IgG fraction on top of the resin of the Zepa spin column.Centrifuge and retain flow-through that contains the buffer exchanged IgG. Discard spin column.After buffer exchange, measure the protein concentration using 280 nm absorbance by nanodrop, if the concentration is less than 100 μg/ml, use Amicon Ultra centrifugation units (4 ml MWCO 50 kDa) to concentrate the IgG to 100-200 μl following the manufacturer’s instruction.After buffer exchange and possibly IgG concentration, filter IgG preparations through a 0.22 μm low protein binding filter under sterile conditions.Aliquot the antibodies as following: one aliquot that can be used for ELISAs and SDS-PAGE gel and kept sterile at 4 °C; and one aliquot that should be frozen and stored at -80 °C for long term storage.Notes: Do not use brake on any of the centrifugations involving the protein G beads, even slight breaking at the end of the spin can cause the beads to fluff, making it difficult to cleanly remove the supernatant. Before starting confirm that elution glycine buffer mixing with the 1 M Tris will give pH 7. If not, adjust the volume of Tris used for neutralization. The time the antibodies are at low pH should be minimized so work fast. When you start the antibody purification, make sure that after elution, immediately buffer exchange to PBS and sterile filter through a 0.22 μm filter under the hood before storage. IgG concentration assessment from purified mAbs (approx. 1 day)Coat ½ area plates with F(ab’)2 antihuman IgG Fab (2 μg/ml in DPBS), 50 μl/well overnight at 4 °C.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.

Block with 100 μl/well of 1% BSA in DPBS and incubate for 1-2 h at room temperature.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Add 50 μl/well of the standard (human IgG1 kappa 200 ng/ml in the first well after that a 1/2 dilution in eight steps down to 1.5 ng/ml, diluted in DPBS with 0.1% BSA).Add 50 μl/well of purified mAbs diluted in DPBS with 0.1% BSA. Use the preliminary concentration by nanodrop 280 nm absorbance for determining the approximate dilution factor that will be required.Incubate for 1-2 h at room temperature.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Dilute the secondary antibody (HRP conjugated F(ab)2 anti-human IgG Fc gamma spec) 1:20,000 in DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Add 50 μl/well of the secondary antibody and incubate for 1 h at room temperature.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Add 50 μl/well of the TMB substrate and incubate for 7-10 min in the dark.Stop reaction by adding 50 μl/well of 0.5 M H2SO4.Read plate at 450 nm, reference filter 650 nm (Figure 6).Notes: It is a very sensitive ELISA so be careful when you do the dilutions. Never use less than 5 μl for diluting samples and the standard. Always reserve two wells for the blank. imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829011214_6486.jpgFigure 6. Example of IgG ELISA data. A. Standard curve for the IgG ELISA. B. Table showing absorbance data and calculation of IgG concentration. Briefly, a linear line is fitted to the standard curve and used to extrapolate concentration values from the absorbances for the different diluted samples. Only absorbance within the linear range of the standard curve are will give an accurate calculation (here highlighted in orange). The final concentration of the IgG stock is calculated by multiplication with the dilution factor.

Calculation can be made manually or by using the ELISA reader software. *. The true conc. values represent the average concentration of the two values of the conc. before adjusting for dilution. SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (approx. 3 h)For each reducing condition prepare and label tubes containing 5 μl of LDS sample Buffer (4x) and 2 μl of Sample Reducing Agent (10x) for reducing conditions.Add 3 μg of each antibody into the corresponding tube. Adjust the final volume to 20 μl with nuclease-free water (if necessary). Run all IgG under both reducing and non-reducing conditions.Place the samples in the heating block at 70 °C for 10 min.Remove the samples from the heating block and spin them down shortly.Place the gel in the tank and fill up the chamber with the 1x MES SDS Running Buffer.Add the samples and a ladder (e.g., See Blue Plus2 prestained ladder) to the gel.Let the electrophoresis go for approximately 40 min (depending on voltage settings).Take the gel out and separate the two plastic plates surrounding it.Use the gel knife to cut around the gel.Rinse the gel in water twice each for 5 min.Heat the gel in Simply Blue Safe Stain on the microwave for 30 s twice.Rinse the gel with water twice each for 5 min.Let the gel be in the water for at least 1 h, preferably overnight.Note: The resulting bands for heavy chain will be between 50 and 60 kDa and the light chain will be between 25 and 30 kDa (Figure 7).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829011313_1663.jpgFigure 7. Example of SDS-PAGE gel picture of purified mAbs. Purified antibodies run on a 4-12% Bis-Tris Plus protein gel using MES-SDS running buffer under reducing (red.) and non-reducing (non-red.) conditions.

The heavy and light chain bands differ slightly in MW from antibody to antibody but typically fall between 50 and 60 kDa for the heavy chain and 25 and 30 kDa for the light chains. Notably, some ACPA mAb carry N-linked glycosylation in the VH or VL regions that will result in a size shift or double bands on the reduced gels. Proper evaluation of the presence of glycosylation can be made by parallel treatment with endoglycosidase (PNGase F compared to EndoS; data not shown). Protein bands are visualized by Coomassie blue staining.Polyreactivity and control ELISAs (approx. 1 day)Polyreactivity ELISA Coat plates with 1 μg/ml of double-stranded DNA, insulin, and LPS, 50 μl/well in DPBS overnight at 4 °C.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Block with 100 μl/well of 1% BSA in DPBS and incubate for at least 1 h at room temperature.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Add 50 μl/well of monoclonal antibodies (5 μg/ml) in the first well after that a 1/3 dilution in DPBS.Incubate for 1 h at room temperature.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Dilute the secondary antibody (HRP conjugated F(ab)2 anti-human IgG Fc gamma spec) 1:20,000 in DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Add 50 μl/well of the secondary antibody and incubate for 1 h at room temperature.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Add 100 μl/well of the TMB substrate and incubate for 7-10 min in the dark.Stop reaction by adding 100 μl/well of 0.5 M H2SO4 Read plate at 450 nm, reference filter 650 nm (Figure 8).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829011419_8278.jpgFigure 8. Graphs showing example of polyreactivity ELISA as tested by dsDNA, LPS and insulin reactivity. Grey lines represent positive mAbs. Black lines represent negative mAbs. Dashed horizontal lines show a cutoff of OD 450 for positive reactivity.

ED38: high-positive polyreactive control antibody (green line); JB40: low-positive polyreactive control antibody (blue line); mGO53: negative control antibody (red line).Notes: Three different control antibodies can be included in the polyreactivity ELISAs; MGO53 (nonreactive), JB40 (weak reactive), and ED38 (high reactive) (Tiller et al., 2008; Agmon-Levin et al., 2014). Antibodies are considered polyreactive when they recognized at least two out of the three analyzed antigens.Anti-Bovine serum albumin (BSA)/plastic, anti-malondialdehyde modified BSA (MDA_BSA) and IgG anti-rabbit IgG ELISAsCoat one ½ area plate with 3 μg/ml of BSA and MDA-BSA (six columns of each antigen on the same plate) and one plate with rabbit IgG, 5 μl/ml in DPBS overnight at 4 °C.Wash plates 1 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Block with 150 μl/well of 3% BSA in DPBS and incubate for 1 h at room temperature.Wash plates 1 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Add 50 μl/well of monoclonal antibodies (5 μg/ml) diluted in 1% BSA in DPBS. Include an RA serum pool on rabbit IgG coated wells as a control to generate a two-fold dilution series starting at around 1:1,000 dilution on every plate.Incubate for 1.5 h at room temperature.Wash 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Dilute the secondary antibody [HRP conjugated rabbit F(ab’)2 anti-human IgG Fc gamma spec] 1:10,000 in 1% BSA in DPBS. Add 50 μl/well of the secondary antibody and incubate for 1 h at room temperature.Wash 4 x with PBS 0.05% Tween 20.Add 50 μl per/well of the TMB substrate and incubate for 10 min in the dark.Stop reaction by adding 50 μl/well of 0.5 M H2SO4.Read plate at 450 nm (Figure 9).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829011502_5609.jpgFigure 9. Example of IgG anti- (BSA)/plastic, -MDA-BSA, and -rabbit IgG ELISA data. The figure shows ELISA plate setup for screening mAbs binding to BSA/plastic, MDA-BSA or rabbit IgG.

In this example, a positive systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patient serum pool is used as a positive control reference for IgG anti-MDA reactivity (here dilution 1:100 is set as 100 Reactivity Units [RU]/ml) and a positive RF IgG containing RA patient serum pool is used as a positive control reference sample on the rabbit IgG surface (here dilution 1:500 is set as 100 RU/ml). Qualification of the mAb reactivity for comparison between ELISA runs can be made by fitting a linear or logarithmic line to the standard curves and extrapolating a relative reactivity in RU/ml from the absorbance values.Notes: It’s important to test all the monoclonal antibodies for BSA binding in parallel to other antigens in the same plate, to ensure that we keep a reasonable incubation time and a standard curve. The BSA assay primarily captures polyreactive antibodies binding to the plastic surface. The MDA-BSA assay can be used for identification of MDA-modified protein autoantibodies but clones that are positive for both MDA and BSA (or rabbit IgG) are considered polyreactive.  The rabbit IgG ELISA captures antibodies with rheumatoid factor activity but could also give false positivity for unstructured or aggregated IgG.Monoclonal antibodies that show binding in the BSA assay or any other control antigen are not considered as citrulline-specific antibodies.Monoclonal antibody screening for citrulline specificities (approx. 1 day)Anti-alpha enolase 1 ELISA Coat ½ area plates with citrullinated and arginine peptides (Table 7) in carbonate buffer pH 9.6, 50 μl/well overnight at 4 °C.Table 7. Citrullinated peptides for screeningimgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829014034_2044.jpgWash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Block with 100 μl/well of 1% BSA in DPBS and incubate for 1-2 h at room temperature.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.

Include a positive RA serum pool as a standard to generate a two-fold dilution series starting at around 1:250 dilution on every plate.Add 50 μl/well in duplicate of monoclonal antibodies (5 μg/ml) diluted in RIA buffer to both arginine and citrulline coated plates.Incubate for 1-2 h at room temperature.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Dilute the secondary antibody (HRP conjugated F(ab’)2 anti-human IgG Fc gamma spec) 1:10,000 in RIA buffer.Add 50 μl/well of the secondary antibody and incubate for 1 h at room temperature.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Add 50 μl/well of the TMB substrate and incubate for 10 min in the dark.Stop reaction by adding 50 μl/well of 0.5 M H2SO4.Read plate at 450 nm, reference filter 650 nm (Figure 10).Notes: All reactive samples were analyzed in at least 3 independent experiments. For each plate, you should have a standard curve of a pool of ACPA + RA serum samples as a control and for standardization of reactivity. Citrulline-reactive mAbs are re-run starting at 5 μg/ml followed by a 2-fold dilution series down to 0.15 ng/ml to generate dilution curves. All identified citrulline-reactive mAbs should be confirmed using large scale expression and quality-controlled IgG batches (verified to be pure and of high quality on SDS-PAGE and without aggregation or endotoxin).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829011533_4741.jpgFigure 10. Example of anti-CEP-1 ELISA data. A. Standard curve for the CEP-1 ELISA using a positive RA reference serum sample (here dilution 1:120 is set to 333 Activity Units (AU)/ml). B. Data showing ACPA-positive (blue bars) and negative mAbs for CEP-1 ELISA at 5 μg/ml IgG. Qualification of the mAb reactivity for comparison between ELISA runs can be made by fitting a linear line to the standard curve and extrapolating a relative reactivity in AU/ml from the absorbance values.

Anti-Cit-fibrinogen, Cit-vimentin and Cit-filaggrin peptide ELISA Wash the streptavidin coated plates 2 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Coat plates with 50 μl/well of citrullinated and arginine peptides (Table 7) in TBE buffer for 1 h at room temperature.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Include a positive RA serum pool as a control to generate a two-fold dilution series starting at around 1:250 dilution on every plate.Add 50 μl/well in duplicate of monoclonal antibodies (5 μg/ml) diluted in RIA buffer to both arginine and citrulline coated plates.Incubate for 1-2 h at room temperature.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Dilute the secondary antibody (HRP conjugated F(ab)2 anti-human IgG Fc gamma specific) 1:10,000 in RIA buffer.Add 50 μl/well of the secondary antibody and incubate for 1 h at room temperature.Wash plates 3 x with DPBS 0.05% Tween 20.Add 100 μl/well of the TMB substrate and incubate for 10-15 min in the dark.Stop reaction by adding 100 μl/well of 0.5 M H2SO4.Read the plate at 450 nm, reference filter 650 nm (Figure 11).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190829/20190829011610_9286.jpgFigure 11. Example of anti cit-Fib 573 (aa563-583) ELISA data. A. Standard curve for the cit-Fib 573 ELISA using a positive RA reference serum [here dilution 1:80 is set to 333 Activity Units (AU)/ml]. B. Data showing ACPA-positive (blue bars) and negative mAbs for cit-Fib 573 ELISA at 5 μg/ml IgG. Qualification of the mAb reactivity for comparison between ELISA runs can be made by fitting a linear line to the standard curve and extrapolating a relative reactivity in AU/ml from the absorbance values.Notes: All reactive samples should be analyzed in at least three independent experiments. For each plate, you should use the standard curve of a pool of ACPA + RA serum samples as a control and for standardization of reactivity.

Citrulline-reactive mAbs are re-run at a concentration of 5 μg/ml then diluted by factor of two down to 0.15 ng/ml to generate dilution curves. All identified citrulline-reactive mAbs should be confirmed using large scale expression and quality-controlled IgG batches (verified to have high purity and of high quality on SDS-PAG and without aggregation or endotoxin). Discard the column. The elution tube contains the purified DNA.Precipitate the DNA using the DNA precipitation units that can be purchased with the kit or alternatively using a centrifuge: Add 10.5 ml isopropanol to the eluate. Mix well and centrifuge the tube at 12,000 x g for 30 min at 4 °C. Discard the supernatant and add 5 ml 70% ethanol (in Milli-Q water) to the pellet. Centrifuge the tube at 12,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C. Remove the supernatant and air-dry the pellet.Add 500 μl of TE Buffer to the purified DNA.Measure the concentration of the DNA plasmid.Store plasmid DNA at -20 °C.Sequence the plasmid before continuing to the large-scale expression (Ab sense primer).Notes: The PureLink kit can be exchanged for another high-purity plasmid preparation kit. Adjust kit size from midi to maxi or mega depending on the amount of plasmid needed for expression. Sequence the maxiprep plasmids and ensure that the quality of the sequences is high. The maxipreps will be the starting point for all subsequent studies. Filter it through a 0.22 μm filter to a new sterile bottle.Notes: Always use freshly prepared PEI-MAX working solutions. Take off supernatant using a pipette, add the same volume of DPBS as previous, then centrifuge again using the same program.Resuspend beads in appropriate volume DPBS or sample supernatant and add the beads to the antibody-containing supernatant.Put flasks containing cell culture supernatant and Protein G beads on the roller (60 rpm) and incubate overnight (at least 14 h) at 4 °C.After incubation, keep the bottles with supernatant and beads on the bench at 4 °C for a while to let the beads sink to the bottom of the flask.Let almost all the supernatant pass through the column. Leave a small amount of supernatant together with the beads.Add the rest of the supernatant together with the protein G beads to the column.Add some PBS to the bead-containing bottle to be able to transfer the remaining beads over to the column.Wash three times each with 30 ml DPBS.Blot the bottom of the column to get rid of excess flow through droplets and place the column on top of a 50 ml tube.Calculate the volume of elution buffer 0.1 M glycine (pH 3.0) based on the approximate total IgG in the supernatant to achieve a concentration of approximately 1.5 mg/ml in the eluted antibody suspension. Protein G Sepharose 4 Fast Flow is a first choice for general-purpose capture of antibodies at laboratory scale. It has a binding capacity of approximately 20 mg/ml of resin.

Before you start antibody purification, mix 100 μl 1 M Tris and 1 ml 0.1 M Glycine and check pH with a filter paper (should be pH 7), if the pH is too high or too low, the amount of 1 M Tris should be adjusted.
